block.p: White House Plans a Bill On Cyberspace Surveillance The White House said that it would propose legislation to set legal requirements for surveillance in cyberspace by law enforcement authorities similar in some ways to those for telephone wiretaps.

Privacy advocates and civil liberties groups welcomed some aspects of the proposal but said they remained alarmed about a new F.B.I. computer system that searches and intercepts private e-mail. [Page A1.]

Books Ordered by Chapter or Verse This fall, hundreds of books like travel guides will be sold on the Internet in parts -- chapters, maps and even paragraphs -- that can be mixed and matched a la carte by readers. Buyers will have the option of receiving their books electronically or ordering them printed, bound and delivered. [A1.]

Ex-U.S. Attorney Is Sentenced A former United States attorney and commodities regulator was sentenced to 24 months in prison for becoming a co-conspirator with the operators of fraudulent telemarketing scams of the type he had once investigated and prosecuted. The sentence received by John A. Field III, 60, was a bit more than one-fourth of the maximum 87-month term he could have faced, reflecting his cooperation with investigators after he was caught. [C2.]

Tylenol to Be Sold in Japan This Fall In a sign that American drug companies are cracking open the Japanese market, Johnson & Johnson will announce today that Tylenol will be available in Japan early this fall. [C4.]

Stocks End Mixed in Light Trading Stocks were mixed in lackluster trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.48 points, or 0.1 percent, to 10,804.27. The Nasdaq composite index rose 28.49 points, or 0.7 percent, to 4,274.67, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 0.51 point, to 1,510.49. [C8.]

Georgia-Pacific to Buy Fort James Georgia-Pacific Group said that it would buy Fort James for $7.5 billion in cash and stock, creating the world's largest maker of tissue as it moves away from the cyclical pulp and paper market. It will also assume $3.5 billion in debt. Shares of Georgia-Pacific fell $2.25, to $26.375, while shares Fort James soared $8.4375, or 34 percent, to $33. [C2.]
Two Law Firms Plan to Merge Two large law firms, Pillsbury Madison & Sutro, based in San Francisco, and Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts, based in New York, announced plans to merge. [C5.]

Prozac Ages, Still Causing a Furor As Prozac edges into adolescence and Eli Lilly's exclusive patent nears expiration, Prozac is causing a stir. Two psychiatrists contend that Prozac and its cousins are often indiscriminately prescribed and have more serious side effects than the public is aware of. [F1.]
